reasoning: Nagana is trypanosomiasis in animals (primarily cattle and other livestock), while human African sleeping sickness (HAT) is the human form. Nagana is not a human disease per se, but zoonotic transmission is extremely rare. Human HAT cases <10,000 per year globally. Nagana in animals affects livestock in sub-Saharan Africa but human infection is <0.01 per 100k.
source: WHO African sleeping sickness surveillance data
